item.description: the main role software has in an organization is to facilitate processes. My friend argued that this is a strict and maybe overly theoretical view of software in the workplace. He might be right, but nevertheless, I think there is an article in this conversation.

item.title: The Truth: What It Really Takes to Build an SaaS
item.description: You ever see a post like "How I made $10K per month with new AI SaaS" and think, "Wow, I should make one"? While that's the ultimate developer dream, I'm here to tell you that this dream isn't as easy as people make it out to be—you've been lied to.

item.title: Even the Rocks are Moving (Evolution) - kupajo
item.description: Nothing sits still. Look at a rock under a powerful microscope, and you’ll see its parts moving. Vibrating particles. Everything is undergoing constant reassembly. Growing, breaking, dying, rebuilding. Energy isn’t created or destroyed, just transformed. It’s all in flux.

item.title: Chef and the Aesthetics of Multicoding
item.description: Programs in the Chef language are also cooking recipes, making Chef a multicoding esolang. Looking to this early example of an esolang that embraces multicoding, we consider what's at stake in these languages and the possibilities of multicoding aesthetics.

item.title: Euge's blog - My bookmarks are public now
item.description: So, Pocket's shutting down. Cue the minor existential crisis for a 10-year power user like myself. Over a thousand articles saved – a digital trail of my internet rabbit holes and "aha!" moments. The announcement hit, and it wasn't just about losing a service; it was about realizing how much of that curated knowledge was locked away, just for me. And the big question: migrate to another silo, or... something else?
